rev.comment: removing comment about art (is implied by loss of emotional depth)
rev.diff:
Line 44: Line 44:
{{spoiler}}
{{spoiler}}
* A selectively-told [[back story]] of a war, revolution, uprising, spike in [[overpopulation]], natural disaster or some other climactic event which resulted in dramatic changes to society
* A selectively-told [[back story]] of a war, revolution, uprising, spike in [[overpopulation]], natural disaster or some other climactic event which resulted in dramatic changes to society
â
* A standard of living among the lower and middle class that is generally poorer than in contemporary society. This is not always the case, however — in ''[[Brave New World]]'' and ''[[Equilibrium (2002 film)|Equilibrium]]'', people enjoy much higher material living standards in exchange for the loss of other qualities in their lives, such as independent thought and emotional depth. (Must be pointed out that the destruction of art could be said to devalue the qulity of lives of characters in ''[[Equilibrium]]''.
+
* A standard of living among the lower and middle class that is generally poorer than in contemporary society. This is not always the case, however — in ''[[Brave New World]]'' and ''[[Equilibrium (2002 film)|Equilibrium]]'', people enjoy much higher material living standards in exchange for the loss of other qualities in their lives, such as independent thought and emotional depth.
* A protagonist who questions the society, often feeling intuitively that something is terribly wrong, such as V from [[Alan Moore]]'s ''[[V for Vendetta]]''.
* A protagonist who questions the society, often feeling intuitively that something is terribly wrong, such as V from [[Alan Moore]]'s ''[[V for Vendetta]]''.
* Necessarily, if it is based on our world, a shift in emphasis of control, e.g. to corporations, autocratic cliques or bureaucracies.
* Necessarily, if it is based on our world, a shift in emphasis of control, e.g. to corporations, autocratic cliques or bureaucracies.
